title: Open ASX blockchain project to disrupters, say critics
text:
Registry groups – which maintain records of shareholder ownership, conduct corporate actions and manage share purchase plans – could be disrupted if ASX extends its blockchain from equities clearing and settlement to registry-type services. Australian investors pay around $1 billion each year for registry services.

A document prepared for the new group says its members have "evidence-based concerns that the replacement project’s primary beneficiary is the ASX, rather than the issuers, investors and participants the project is purported to benefit".

The founding members are three registry companies (Computershare, Link Group and BoardRoom), three industry groups (Australian Investor Relations Association, Governance Institute of Australia, and SAFAA) and consumer group the Australian Shareholders Association (ASA).

Mr Stevens told The Australian Financial Review's Chanticleer column that the ASX has consulted widely with relevant stakeholders and that the new system could help to reduce the $23 billion it costs to run the superannuation system each year.

He said there are no structural impediments to competition in the settlement and clearing space, and predicted a challenger could emerge.

But members of the new lobby group say the project could entrench the ASX's market power and that the prospects of a competitive market are diminished unless potential competitors gain access to more information.

Fiona Balzer, policy manager at the ASA and a former infrastructure sector analyst at Westpac, said Australia’s equity settlement and clearing system is effectively a piece of critical national infrastructure and should be subject to the same conditions and regulatory settings as other big infrastructure projects.

Advertisement

“You need a third-party access regime and you need the competition authority’s oversight,” she said. “The power of a regulated company which trades on the market it manages itself is just a whole bunch of conflicts stuck in one place.”

The stakeholder group is calling on the federal government to mandate that the ASX provide access to its intellectual property to third parties, such as fintech start-ups, which could potentially help develop rival offerings.

“A third-party access regime would actually facilitate the ability for disrupters to take a look at this technology and actually be able to innovate,” Ms Balzer said.

She suggested there is no shortage of "financial minds" in Australia who can benefit from participation in an access regime and come up with competitive solutions, including existing share registry providers.

'Creative destruction'

Judith Fox, chief executive of the SAFAA, said her organisation supports the overall move to a more technologically advanced settlement and clearing system, but is fearful about the ASX’s conflicted role in operating it.

“We are not anti-innovation. I know it’s easy to portray us as luddites, but that’s not what’s going on here,” Ms Fox said. “The idea of a distributed ledger technology platform is a really sound one and we support that and we support innovation.

"The concern is primarily around competition because ASX is a publicly listed, for-profit company, and is positioning itself to effectively monopolise what will be a valuable piece of national infrastructure.”

Advertisement

The only founding member of the stakeholder group solely representing the interests of investors – the ASA – is not motivated by the survival of share registries, but it does believe they play an important role in holding the ASX to account.

“We would be concerned about these organisations being disrupted and taken out of the market if it wasn’t a contested market,” said Ms Balzer.

“Being disrupted and then replaced by something equally strong and competitive is different than being taken out and replaced by the ASX.”

Ms Balzer said the share registries had lifted their game in recent years through investing in online portals, following criticism from retail investors.

Computershare reported total revenue in the last financial year of $2.4 billion, with 10 per cent of this earned in Australia. Link, meanwhile, reported $1.4 billion in revenue, with $700 million made in Australia.

The three share registry founding members declined to comment, instead referring The Australian Financial Review to fellow members, the Governance Institute and AIRA.

Computershare said in its recent annual report that the “ultimate market structure implications [from blockchain] are not yet known”.

Yet it said it is adopting a “measured and considered approach” to the technology, including “pursing a dual-track approach in terms of assessing the commercial value of introducing innovative blockchain services in market adjacencies, while also rigorously defending our existing role and overall market positioning''.

Advertisement

Ms Fox agreed that the share registries could potentially be disrupted, but rejected suggestions that their motivation in criticising the CHESS replacement project stems from self-interest entirely.

“Capitalism is creative destruction, businesses rise and fall – that’s not the issue,” she said. “Yes, the share registries might be thinking about their self-interest, but there is also that concern about competition. At the heart of the concern is the conflict of interest whereby the ASX is project manager, the future operator and a for-profit entity.”

SPPs and privacy

ASA had had "a lot of meetings" with ASX about the project, "but we still can’t get much detail out of [ASX]," Ms Balzer said. "They have very charming people and they give us lots of information, but they don’t answer any specifics around the complexity.”

The ASA is concerned that an unintended consequence of the CHESS replacement could be that retail investors get muscled out of the market for share purchase plans and other capital raising opportunities.

“There is talk of the ASX putting all the potential take-up [for] an SPP [share purchase plan] on to the system, and even if it was one cent for each potential take-up, it could make companies think twice about offering up SPPs to all shareholders,” Ms Balzer said.

They have very charming people and they give us lots of information, but they don’t answer any specifics around the complexity. — Fiona Balzer, ASA

“That might mean that shareholders who rely on those sorts of capital offers to not be diluted by the big end of town will not be offered those sorts of catch-ups in the future.”

Advertisement

The common practice in the market is that brokers will only register investors who are actively participating in the offer in CHESS, Ms Balzer said, meaning that the administrative costs for issuers are reduced.

The fear around prospective investors being registered in CHESS without actively participating in an offer also raises privacy risks, she said.

Under the incumbent system, brokers often do not enter bank account and other private information into CHESS because there is no requirement to do so and there are costs associated with updating data.

“Sometimes that can be annoying but retail shareholders own that data and should decide who can get access to that data,” Ms Balzer said. “They don’t want data accessed willy-nilly.”

A working paper compiled by Deloitte on behalf of the stakeholder group raises a number of other privacy and data concerns.

“The replacement project will drive functional changes resulting in an expansion in the scope of consumer data shared,” the working paper said.

“It will also change how/where data is stored, and who will have access to it. This raises not only privacy concerns, but also questions as to the purpose of a market operator moving into a data holder role.”

The ASX disputes such concerns about data. Mr Stevens said the ASX had no intention of taking more data or charging investors “any more money”, but instead was focused on building a technology system for the next 20 or 30 years.
description: The ASX's new settlement and clearing system should be classified as critical national infrastructure and opened up to fintech challengers, say stakeholders.
